subject: RE: [junit] JUnit Design?
msgSnippet: ... If the problem is only potential (and may only hit you once a year) a normal developer (myself included) will most likely not put the extra effort to write
messageBody:
> These problems can be mitigated by including thorough postcondition and
> invariant validation at the end of east test.

If the problem is only potential (and may only hit you once a year) a normal
developer (myself included) will most likely not put the extra effort to write
pre- and postconditions for every test/testcase. And when it finally hits you,
you're sure to spend hours (if not days) finding and fixing the problem.

Someone pointed out a few months ago that the JUnit tests are not executed in
the same order depending on the vm used. If your tests are order-dependant it's
also an issue.

Considering that you have simple ways to share resources, I wonder if having one
test object and invoking all of its test methods is the best solution.

-Vladimir
